low_recommendations.supplements: Consider iron supplements with Vitamin C for better absorption
low_recommendations.lifestyle: Avoid tea/coffee with meals as they reduce iron absorption

high_recommendations.diet: Stay well hydrated, reduce red meat intake
high_recommendations.lifestyle: Quit smoking if applicable, consult doctor for polycythemia screening

low_recommendations.lifestyle: Eat regular small meals, don't skip breakfast

diet: Low GI foods: Oats, quinoa, vegetables
Avoid: White rice, sugary drinks, pastries
high_recommendations.lifestyle: Monitor blood sugar regularly, maintain healthy weight

diet: Avoid trans fats and fried foods
Avoid: Butter, red meat, processed foods
Eat: Vegetables, whole grains, lean proteins

recommendations.lifestyle: Consult doctor if persistently abnormal, avoid infections, adequate rest

diet: Avoid goitrogens in excess (raw cruciferous vegetables)
high_recommendations.lifestyle: May need thyroid medication, consult endocrinologist

recommendations.diet: Reduce protein if high, stay hydrated
recommendations.lifestyle: Monitor kidney function, consult nephrologist if persistently high

diet: Avoid: Red meat, organ meats, alcohol, sugary drinks
recommendations.lifestyle: Stay hydrated, maintain healthy weight, limit alcohol

diabetes.name: Diabetes / High Blood Sugar

eat: Low GI foods: Steel-cut oats, quinoa, barley
Low GI fruits: Berries, apples, pears
avoid: High GI fruits: Mango, pineapple, watermelon
dietary_guidelines.meal_timing: Eat small frequent meals every 3-4 hours

diabetes.monitoring: Check blood sugar regularly, HbA1c every 3 months

hypertension.name: High Blood Pressure

eat: DASH diet: Fruits, vegetables, whole grains

hypertension.lifestyle: Reduce stress, adequate sleep, maintain healthy weight

anemia.name: Anemia / Low Hemoglobin

eat: Vitamin C foods: Citrus fruits, tomatoes (enhances iron absorption)
Folic acid: Leafy greens, fortified cereals
avoid: Tea and coffee with meals (reduces iron absorption)
dietary_guidelines.cooking_tips: Use iron cookware, soak beans overnight

anemia.supplements: Iron supplements (325mg ferrous sulfate) with Vitamin C

eat: Iodine-rich: Sea fish, dairy, iodized salt
dietary_guidelines.timing: Take thyroid medication on empty stomach, 30 mins before food

exercise_guidelines.note: May feel fatigued initially, start slow

limit: Phosphorus: Limit dairy, nuts, processed foods
dietary_guidelines.hydration: Fluid restriction may be needed in advanced stages

benefits: Rich in pectin (fiber) which lowers bad cholesterol
High in Vitamin C to boost immunity
Contains polyphenols that help regulate blood sugar
apple.hemoglobin_role: Contains small amounts of iron and vitamin C which aids iron absorption from other foods.

benefits: Improves blood flow and heart health
pomegranate.hemoglobin_role: Top fruit for boosting Hemoglobin. High in iron, vitamins A, C, and E. Increases RBC count directly.

benefits: High in nitrates which lower blood pressure
beetroot.hemoglobin_role: Excellent for raising Hemoglobin. It repairs and reactivates RBCs, increasing oxygen supply to the body.

benefits: Rich in lutein for eye health
spinach.hemoglobin_role: The gold standard plant-based iron source. Best taken with citrus to maximize absorption.

benefits: Contains papain enzyme which aids protein digestion
High in Vitamin A and Lycopene
papaya.hemoglobin_role: Contains folic acid which is essential for RBC production. Known to help boost Platelet count.

lemon_and_citrus.hemoglobin_role: CRITICAL: Vitamin C is required to absorb non-heme (plant) iron. Always squeeze lemon on spinach or lentils.

almonds_and_walnuts.hemoglobin_role: Provides copper and vitamins that assist in hemoglobin synthesis.

benefits: Excellent source of potassium for nerve function
banana.hemoglobin_role: Contains Vitamin B6 and folate which are vital for healthy blood cells.

berries.hemoglobin_role: Supports healthy blood vessels and circulatory health.

guava.hemoglobin_role: Massive Vitamin C content ensures all iron from your diet is absorbed effectively.

greetings: Hello! I'm your Health Assistant. How can I help you today?
Hi there! Ready to discuss your health and fitness?
Welcome! Ask me anything about your blood reports, diet, or workouts.
conversational_templates.report_summary_intro: Based on your latest blood report from {date}, here's what I found:
conversational_templates.no_reports: I don't see any blood reports uploaded yet. You can upload one in the Blood Evaluation section to get personalized insights!
conversational_templates.normal_report: Great news! Your latest blood report shows all parameters within normal range. Keep up the good work! 🌟
conversational_templates.disclaimer: ⚠️ This is AI-generated advice based on general guidelines. Always consult your doctor for medical decisions.

blood_report_and_lab_values.question: What is creatinine and why does it increase?
blood_report_and_lab_values.answer: Creatinine is a waste product from muscle breakdown, filtered by the kidneys. It increases when kidney function is impaired, or due to severe dehydration and high protein intake.

blood_report_and_lab_values.question: How can I reduce my creatinine level naturally?
blood_report_and_lab_values.answer: Stay well-hydrated, reduce intense exercise temporarily, and limit high-protein foods like red meat if your levels are elevated.

blood_report_and_lab_values.question: What causes high urea levels in the blood?
blood_report_and_lab_values.answer: High urea (BUN) can be caused by kidney dysfunction, dehydration, high protein intake, or even certain medications.

blood_report_and_lab_values.question: What does a low hemoglobin level indicate?
blood_report_and_lab_values.answer: Low hemoglobin typically indicates anemia, which means your blood isn't carrying enough oxygen. It's often caused by iron, B12, or folate deficiency.

blood_report_and_lab_values.question: How can I increase my hemoglobin quickly?
blood_report_and_lab_values.answer: Eat iron-rich foods (red meat, spinach, lentils) along with Vitamin C (lemon, citrus) to boost absorption. Pomegranate and beetroot are excellent natural boosters.

blood_report_and_lab_values.question: What is the normal range for white blood cells (WBC)?
blood_report_and_lab_values.answer: The normal WBC range is generally between 4,000 and 11,000 cells per microliter (mcL).

blood_report_and_lab_values.question: What does a high WBC count mean?
blood_report_and_lab_values.answer: A high WBC count (leukocytosis) usually indicates your body is fighting an infection, inflammation, or responding to high stress.

blood_report_and_lab_values.question: Why might my platelet count be low?
blood_report_and_lab_values.answer: Low platelets (thrombocytopenia) can be caused by viral infections (like Dengue), vitamin B12 deficiency, or certain immune conditions.

blood_report_and_lab_values.question: How can I improve my platelet count naturally?
blood_report_and_lab_values.answer: Papaya leaf extract, pomegranate, and Vitamin B12-rich foods can help support healthy platelet production.

blood_report_and_lab_values.question: What does a high ESR value indicate?
blood_report_and_lab_values.answer: ESR (Erythrocyte Sedimentation Rate) is a non-specific marker for inflammation in the body. It increases during infections or chronic inflammatory conditions.

blood_report_and_lab_values.question: What does a low RBC count mean?
blood_report_and_lab_values.answer: A low RBC count means your body has fewer oxygen-carrying cells than normal, often leading to fatigue and weakness (Anemia).

blood_report_and_lab_values.question: How can I increase my RBC count through diet?
blood_report_and_lab_values.answer: Focus on iron, Vitamin B12, and folic acid. Leafy greens, eggs, and fortified cereals are key.

blood_report_and_lab_values.question: What is bilirubin, and why might it be high?
blood_report_and_lab_values.answer: Bilirubin is a yellowish pigment from old red blood cells. High levels often indicate liver issues, gallbladder blockages, or high breakdown of RBCs (Jaundice).

blood_report_and_lab_values.question: What causes elevated liver enzymes (SGPT, SGOT)?
blood_report_and_lab_values.answer: Elevation usually signals liver cell damage, often caused by fatty liver, alcohol consumption, certain medications, or viral hepatitis.

blood_report_and_lab_values.question: What is the normal blood sugar level?
blood_report_and_lab_values.answer: Fasting blood sugar is normally 70–99 mg/dL. 100–125 mg/dL is pre-diabetic, and 126+ mg/dL indicates diabetes.

blood_report_and_lab_values.question: How to control high fasting blood sugar?
blood_report_and_lab_values.answer: Reduce evening carb intake, increase fiber, ensure 7+ hours of sleep, and stay active with daily walking.

blood_report_and_lab_values.question: What does a high HbA1c mean?
blood_report_and_lab_values.answer: HbA1c measures your average blood sugar over the past 3 months. A high level indicates poor long-term sugar control (6.5%+ is diabetic).

blood_report_and_lab_values.question: What does low vitamin D in my blood report mean?
blood_report_and_lab_values.answer: Low Vit D can lead to bone pain and weak immunity. It's often due to lack of sun exposure or poor absorption.

blood_report_and_lab_values.question: How can I increase vitamin D naturally?
blood_report_and_lab_values.answer: Sunlight (15-20 min daily) is the best source. Fatty fish, egg yolks, and fortified milk also help.

blood_report_and_lab_values.question: What are the symptoms of low vitamin B12?
blood_report_and_lab_values.answer: Common signs include fatigue, dizziness, numbness in hands/feet, and brain fog.

blood_report_and_lab_values.question: How can I increase vitamin B12 levels?
blood_report_and_lab_values.answer: Meat, fish, eggs, and dairy are the best sources. Vegans often need supplements or fortified foods.

blood_report_and_lab_values.question: What causes high cholesterol in the blood?
blood_report_and_lab_values.answer: Diets high in saturated/trans fats, lack of exercise, smoking, and genetics are the primary causes.

blood_report_and_lab_values.question: How can I lower my LDL cholesterol naturally?
blood_report_and_lab_values.answer: Increase soluble fiber (oats, beans), eat nuts, and use olive oil instead of butter.

blood_report_and_lab_values.question: What is HDL cholesterol and how can I increase it?
blood_report_and_lab_values.answer: HDL is 'good' cholesterol that protects your heart. Increase it with regular cardio and healthy fats like fish and walnuts.

blood_report_and_lab_values.question: What does high triglyceride mean?
blood_report_and_lab_values.answer: High triglycerides are a type of fat in your blood. High levels increase heart risk and are often due to excess sugar, alcohol, and calories.

blood_report_and_lab_values.question: How can I reduce triglycerides fast?
blood_report_and_lab_values.answer: Cut out sugar, refined carbs, and alcohol. Increase physical activity and eat omega-3 rich foods.

blood_report_and_lab_values.question: What does high uric acid mean?
blood_report_and_lab_values.answer: High uric acid can lead to Gout (joint pain). It's caused by a diet rich in purines (red meat, seafood) and sugar.

blood_report_and_lab_values.question: How to lower uric acid naturally?
blood_report_and_lab_values.answer: Drink plenty of water, avoid red meat and sugary drinks, and eat low-fat dairy and cherries.

blood_report_and_lab_values.question: What is CRP and why is it tested?
blood_report_and_lab_values.answer: CRP (C-Reactive Protein) is a marker of inflammation. It helps detect acute infections or chronic inflammatory risks.

blood_report_and_lab_values.question: What does a high CRP level indicate?
blood_report_and_lab_values.answer: It means there is significant inflammation in your body. It could be due to a recent infection, injury, or an underlying chronic condition.

kidney_and_liver_health.question: What foods support kidney function?
kidney_and_liver_health.answer: Hydrating foods like cucumber, water-rich fruits like apples/berries, and low-sodium vegetables.

kidney_and_liver_health.question: Can dehydration cause high creatinine?
kidney_and_liver_health.answer: Yes, dehydration reduces the volume of blood filtered by the kidneys, which can cause a temporary spike in creatinine.

kidney_and_liver_health.question: What are the early symptoms of kidney disease?
kidney_and_liver_health.answer: Fatigue, swelling in ankles (edema), changes in urination frequency, and foamy urine.

kidney_and_liver_health.question: How much water should I drink for healthy kidneys?
kidney_and_liver_health.answer: Generally 3-4 liters for men and 2.5-3 liters for women, adjusted for activity and weather.

kidney_and_liver_health.question: What foods should I avoid if my urea is high?
kidney_and_liver_health.answer: Limit high-protein foods like red meat, organ meats, and excessive legumes until levels stabilize.

kidney_and_liver_health.question: Can exercise help lower creatinine?
kidney_and_liver_health.answer: Moderate exercise supports overall health, but intense weightlifting can actually spike creatinine because it's a byproduct of muscle metabolism.

kidney_and_liver_health.question: What are liver function tests (LFTs)?
kidney_and_liver_health.answer: A group of blood tests (SGPT, SGOT, Bilirubin, Albumin) that measure how well your liver is working.

kidney_and_liver_health.question: What foods help cleanse the liver?
kidney_and_liver_health.answer: Leafy greens, garlic, beets, and turmeric support the liver's natural detoxification process.

kidney_and_liver_health.question: Can alcohol increase SGPT and SGOT?
kidney_and_liver_health.answer: Yes, regular or excessive alcohol causes liver inflammation, which raises these enzyme levels.

kidney_and_liver_health.question: What are signs of fatty liver in blood tests?
kidney_and_liver_health.answer: Mildly elevated SGPT/SGOT and high SGPT-to-SGOT ratio are common markers for fatty liver.

kidney_and_liver_health.question: How to reverse fatty liver naturally?
kidney_and_liver_health.answer: Lose weight through a low-carb diet, quit alcohol, and engage in daily physical activity.

kidney_and_liver_health.question: Can turmeric help with liver health?
kidney_and_liver_health.answer: Yes, curcumin in turmeric has potent anti-inflammatory effects that support liver healing.

kidney_and_liver_health.question: How often should I check my kidney function?
kidney_and_liver_health.answer: Healthy adults should check once a year. Those with diabetes or BP should check every 3-6 months.

kidney_and_liver_health.question: What is eGFR and what does it indicate?
kidney_and_liver_health.answer: eGFR (Estimated Glomerular Filtration Rate) is the best marker for kidney function. Higher is better; below 60 suggests kidney issue.

kidney_and_liver_health.question: What are the causes of low albumin levels?
kidney_and_liver_health.answer: Low albumin can indicate liver disease, kidney issues, or chronic inflammation/malnutrition.

heart_and_cholesterol.question: What causes high LDL cholesterol?
heart_and_cholesterol.answer: Saturated fats (butter, fried food), trans fats, inactivity, and genetics.

heart_and_cholesterol.question: Which foods increase HDL (good cholesterol)?
heart_and_cholesterol.answer: Walnuts, fatty fish (salmon), flaxseeds, and olive oil.

heart_and_cholesterol.question: How to lower cholesterol without medicine?
heart_and_cholesterol.answer: Eat more oats/fiber, avoid trans fats, walk 30 mins daily, and lose excess body fat.

heart_and_cholesterol.question: What is the normal triglyceride level?
heart_and_cholesterol.answer: Below 150 mg/dL is considered normal. Above 200 is high.

heart_and_cholesterol.question: Can stress cause high cholesterol?
heart_and_cholesterol.answer: Yes, stress triggers cortisol, which can increase the production of triglycerides and bad cholesterol.

heart_and_cholesterol.question: Is omega-3 good for heart health?
heart_and_cholesterol.answer: Absolutely. It reduces triglycerides, lowers BP slightly, and reduces the risk of irregular heartbeats.

heart_and_cholesterol.question: How does blood pressure affect heart health?
heart_and_cholesterol.answer: High blood pressure (Hypertension) strains the heart and damages arteries, increasing the risk of heart attack and stroke.

heart_and_cholesterol.question: What foods can help control high blood pressure?
heart_and_cholesterol.answer: Potassium-rich foods like bananas and spinach, and nitrate-rich ones like beetroot.

heart_and_cholesterol.question: Can exercise lower cholesterol?
heart_and_cholesterol.answer: Yes, regular aerobic exercise increases HDL (good) and helps reduce LDL (bad) cholesterol.

heart_and_cholesterol.question: What are warning signs of heart disease in blood tests?
heart_and_cholesterol.answer: High LDL, high triglycerides, high CRP (inflammation), and high Homocysteine.

nutrition_and_vitamins.question: What are the best foods to boost iron levels?
nutrition_and_vitamins.answer: Red meat, liver, spinach, lentils, and pomegranate.

nutrition_and_vitamins.question: Can low iron cause fatigue?
nutrition_and_vitamins.answer: Yes, low iron leads to low hemoglobin, which means less oxygen reaches your organs, causing tiredness.

nutrition_and_vitamins.question: How to increase vitamin C naturally?
nutrition_and_vitamins.answer: Eat bell peppers, citrus fruits (lemon, orange), strawberries, and guava.

nutrition_and_vitamins.question: What are the symptoms of calcium deficiency?
nutrition_and_vitamins.answer: Muscle cramps, brittle nails, and in severe cases, weakened bones or heart rhythm issues.

nutrition_and_vitamins.question: How to increase calcium absorption?
nutrition_and_vitamins.answer: Ensure you have adequate Vitamin D, as the body cannot absorb calcium without it.

nutrition_and_vitamins.question: What foods are rich in folic acid?
nutrition_and_vitamins.answer: Leafy green vegetables (foliage), beans, peas, and fortified grains.

nutrition_and_vitamins.question: What are the signs of low magnesium?
nutrition_and_vitamins.answer: Muscle twitches, fatigue, irregular heartbeat, and difficulty sleeping.

nutrition_and_vitamins.question: How to increase potassium levels naturally?
nutrition_and_vitamins.answer: Bananas, sweet potatoes, coconut water, and white beans are great sources.

nutrition_and_vitamins.question: Can diet affect blood test results?
nutrition_and_vitamins.answer: Significantly. Recent meals, hydration levels, and alcohol can change sugar, lipid, and enzyme readings.

nutrition_and_vitamins.question: Should I fast before a blood test?
nutrition_and_vitamins.answer: For Sugar and Lipid profile (Cholesterol), a 10-12 hour fast is usually required.

nutrition_and_vitamins.question: How to detox the body naturally?
nutrition_and_vitamins.answer: Your liver and kidneys are your main detox organs. Support them with hydration, fiber, and avoiding processed toxins/alcohol.

nutrition_and_vitamins.question: Which fruits are good for blood purification?
nutrition_and_vitamins.answer: Beetroot, pomegranate, cranberries, and apples are excellent for supporting blood health.

nutrition_and_vitamins.question: Can lack of sleep affect blood reports?
nutrition_and_vitamins.answer: Yes, it can increase cortisol (stress hormone), spike sugar levels, and raise BP.

nutrition_and_vitamins.question: What are the best foods for improving immunity?
nutrition_and_vitamins.answer: Vitamin C fruits, garlic, ginger, turmeric, and zinc-rich seeds like pumpkin seeds.

nutrition_and_vitamins.question: How much protein should I eat daily?
nutrition_and_vitamins.answer: Sedentary adults need about 0.8-1g per kg body weight; active adults need 1.2-2g.

diabetes_and_blood_sugar.question: What is HbA1c and why is it important?
diabetes_and_blood_sugar.answer: It shows your average blood sugar over 3 months. It's the most reliable test for identifying long-term sugar trends.

diabetes_and_blood_sugar.question: How to lower blood sugar naturally?
diabetes_and_blood_sugar.answer: Increase fiber, walk 15 mins after every meal, manage stress, and choose low-GI whole foods.

diabetes_and_blood_sugar.question: What are the early symptoms of diabetes?
diabetes_and_blood_sugar.answer: Frequent urination, excessive thirst, sudden weight loss, and slow-healing wounds.

diabetes_and_blood_sugar.question: Can walking reduce blood sugar?
diabetes_and_blood_sugar.answer: Yes, light walking after meals helps muscles use the glucose from your blood, preventing sugar spikes.

diabetes_and_blood_sugar.question: What foods cause blood sugar spikes?
diabetes_and_blood_sugar.answer: Refined sugar, white rice, white bread, pastries, and sweetened juices.

diabetes_and_blood_sugar.question: Is intermittent fasting safe for diabetics?
diabetes_and_blood_sugar.answer: It can be beneficial but MUST be done under medical supervision to avoid dangerous sugar crashes (hypoglycemia).

diabetes_and_blood_sugar.question: How to control sugar cravings?
diabetes_and_blood_sugar.answer: Eat more protein and fiber, stay hydrated, and ensure you're getting enough sleep.

diabetes_and_blood_sugar.question: What fruits are safe for diabetics?
diabetes_and_blood_sugar.answer: Apples, Berries, Guava, and Pears are safer due to their lower GI and high fiber.

diabetes_and_blood_sugar.question: Can stress increase blood sugar levels?
diabetes_and_blood_sugar.answer: Yes, stress hormones (cortisol and adrenaline) signal the liver to release extra glucose into the blood.

diabetes_and_blood_sugar.question: What is the normal range of post-meal glucose?
diabetes_and_blood_sugar.answer: Ideally under 140 mg/dL two hours after eating for a healthy individual.

hormones_and_general_health.question: What does TSH mean in a blood report?
hormones_and_general_health.answer: TSH measures your thyroid function. High TSH means your thyroid is underactive (Hypothyroidism); Low TSH means overactive (Hyperthyroidism).

hormones_and_general_health.question: What are symptoms of thyroid imbalance?
hormones_and_general_health.answer: Weight changes, fatigue, hair loss, feeling too cold or too hot, and mood shifts.

hormones_and_general_health.question: How can I control hypothyroidism naturally?
hormones_and_general_health.answer: Ensure adequate iodine and selenium, avoid excess soy/raw cruciferous veg, and manage stress.

hormones_and_general_health.question: What is cortisol and how does stress affect it?
hormones_and_general_health.answer: Cortisol is the stress hormone. Chronic stress keeps it high, which leads to weight gain, high BP, and high sugar.

hormones_and_general_health.question: How does dehydration affect blood reports?
hormones_and_general_health.answer: It can artificially inflate readings for hemoglobin, hematocrit, and creatinine.

hormones_and_general_health.question: What are signs of anemia?
hormones_and_general_health.answer: Pale skin, dizziness, shortness of breath, cold hands/feet, and constant fatigue.

hormones_and_general_health.question: Can lack of sleep change hormone levels?
hormones_and_general_health.answer: Yes, it lowers growth hormone and spikes cortisol and ghrelin (hunger hormone).

hormones_and_general_health.question: What are symptoms of vitamin deficiency?
hormones_and_general_health.answer: Cracked mouth corners (Vit B), night blindness (Vit A), brittle hair (Zinc), and fatigue (Iron/B12).

hormones_and_general_health.question: How can I boost energy naturally?
hormones_and_general_health.answer: Eat complex carbs, stay hydrated, maintain B12 levels, and get consistent sunlight.

hormones_and_general_health.question: What is the importance of regular blood tests?
hormones_and_general_health.answer: They act as an early warning system, detecting issues like high sugar or organ strain before symptoms appear.

lifestyle_and_ai_guidance.question: How often should I test my blood levels?
lifestyle_and_ai_guidance.answer: Once a year for healthy adults. Every 3-6 months if you have a chronic condition like diabetes or high BP.

lifestyle_and_ai_guidance.question: Can I get diet suggestions based on my blood report?
lifestyle_and_ai_guidance.answer: Yes! Our AI analyzes your report and provides customized diet plans (Anemia diet, Diabetic diet, etc.) based on your results.

lifestyle_and_ai_guidance.question: What exercise is best for improving my health reports?
lifestyle_and_ai_guidance.answer: A mix of 150 mins/week moderate cardio (fasting or after-meal walking) and 2 days of strength training.

lifestyle_and_ai_guidance.question: Should I take supplements if my vitamin levels are low?
lifestyle_and_ai_guidance.answer: Usually yes, but it's best to confirm the dosage with your doctor after seeing the blood report values.

lifestyle_and_ai_guidance.question: What foods should I avoid if I have high cholesterol?
lifestyle_and_ai_guidance.answer: Fried snacks, buttery pastries, red meat, and processed meats like sausages.

lifestyle_and_ai_guidance.question: Can AI help track my blood results over time?
lifestyle_and_ai_guidance.answer: Yes, our AI monitors your trends across multiple reports to see if your health is improving or declining over time.

lifestyle_and_ai_guidance.question: How to know if my diet is affecting my blood report?
lifestyle_and_ai_guidance.answer: Consistent diet changes will show in your sugar (glucose/HbA1c) and lipid (cholesterol) levels in 2-3 months.

lifestyle_and_ai_guidance.question: How to maintain healthy blood pressure naturally?
lifestyle_and_ai_guidance.answer: Lower salt intake, exercise daily, lose abdominal fat, and manage stress through meditation.

lifestyle_and_ai_guidance.question: Can stress cause abnormal blood results?
lifestyle_and_ai_guidance.answer: Definitely. Stress can spike glucose, cholesterol, BP, and even WBC count.

lifestyle_and_ai_guidance.question: How can your AI chatbot help me understand my blood report?
lifestyle_and_ai_guidance.answer: Our AI acts as a proactive health coach. It doesn't just read values; it analyzes trends, explains medical terminology, and provides specific diet and lifestyle steps based on YOUR data.
